--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Ashot Petrosian" <ashot@m...> wrote:

> >
> > 	I'd just like to say that it would be nice if we no longer had
benchmarks which were defined as the task only, sans the fitness
function.  The fitness function has so much to do in shaping the
landscape that I don't understand how its sensible to say something
like "we can solve the ___ task."  It is essentially possible to cheat
to solve a task by constructing a fitness function which is
multi-tiered and points the algorithm in the right direction to the
solution for most complicated problems, right?  Or am I just crazy?
> >
> >
>
I agree with the sentiment but in practice it turns out people
generally follow your recommendation anyway.  Most people who do pole
balancing, for example, follow the same fitness criterion as their
predecessors.  And if they didn't, they would generally report the
discrepency.  It would be a bit disingenuous to claim solving a task
that is actually using a different fitness function than normal.

ken
